review_title: A good place to start, and that's about it.
job_title: Research Assistant I in Toronto, ON
pros: Baycrest has a very flexible work environment - come in any time and leave after your 8 hours are done. No micro-management at the lab, but depends on which lab you are in. The IT department is ridiculously awesome, but you won't find that awesomeness everywhere. The Friday tea times were very fun and a good way to keep the staff informed about informal events going on at the research centre.
cons: The clientele can be exceptionally demanding, especially if you are running clinical studies. It is also hard to get time with a good statistician. Sometimes you just get treated like a live statistics machine and psychometrist, with no input into data interpretation or the write-up. Can get frustrating for those who like to be in control of work from start to finish. Also, no benefits because they keep all research assistants on contract, and they get btchy about approving vacation time (for no apparent reason).

pros:
- warm environment
- well resourced workplace (I have access to all the equipment and other resources I need to do my job)
- infrastructure (REB, IT, etc)  that works exceptionally well to facilitate our work with minimal red tape - really stands out compared to other institutions I have worked at
- amazing colleagues and research participants
- learning opportunities (research talks, seminars, etc)
- experience in any company will depend a lot on your own manager - mine is amazing
- senior management and executive are approachable
- CEO that really tries to engage and communicate with staff; opportunities to provide input, and feel heard
- Jewish high holidays off
cons:
- not as well known or glitzy as the downtown research hospitals
- over-researched population makes recruitment for almost any study challenging
- multiple 1-year contracts with no benefits for several years

review_title: Decent pay, extremely poor working environment and growth opportunities (research)
pros: My position was 9-5, pay was fair
cons:
-Little to no direction from higher ups. As a new employee I had to navigate this all on my own and from coworkers rather than my employer. 
-Often overheard really discriminatory language from baycrest employees ex. how mexicans are bad people, making fun of dreads. The list goes on and on...
-They treat lower employees and volunteers like crap ex. joking about taking advantage of youth who are there to learn by making them wash their cars
-HR is a mess. It was very clear through the hiring and firing process that baycrest HR is very disorganized and unprofessional. 

Moral: Go to any of the other research hospitals in toronto for a better work environment and learning opportunities

review_title: Organization which tries hard to live its mission and vision - but not there yet
pros:
Values of CARE (Client Centred Care, Advocacy, Respect & Excellence) are supported in daily work. 

People are great

True contribution to community
cons:
Safe learning environment /learning from mistakes is a thing of the past with new leadership

Poor communication - areas of organization going in different directions / not communicating & understanding each other's objectives at front line level

WIGS (wildly important goals) program is praised by management but not supported by staff 

Refers to itself as a learning organization, but this is not seen in practice - minimal staff / leadership development opportunities

review_title: Great place to work if you want to stay in healthcare sector
pros:
- opportunities for advancement if you have clinical background
- many people have been working here for a long time
- if you have a supportive manager, you can expand your role based on interests
- interesting work and projects, great if you are interested in impacting the lives of others
cons:
- environment feels toxic at times
- your experience depends on your manager and their management style/level of support
- sometimes my job does not feel secure
- people stay in roles for a long time, only few advance
- unionized environment, it feels like the unions hold a lot of power

job_title: Personal Support Worker in Toronto, ON
pros: Great work environment with a wonderful team.   Management is understanding, helpful, and encouraging.  I am currently in a nursing program and during my time at Baycrest each staff member has gone above and beyond to further my education and experience.   Although I'm part time I receive plenty of work hours, so long as you make yourself available.  Above all else, it's a rewarding job that allows you to help others!
cons: Not every staff member is as enthusiastic about there job as others, and that sometimes reflects in teamwork and communication.  That being said, you would find that in every position or career.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Toronto, ON
pros:
This hospital is positioned well in the future of healthcare. There is strong leadership with dynamic personalities that will guide Baycrest forward, especially in a climate of limited public funding. Baycrest has a lot of promise.
On a more practical note, Baycrest offers good benefits, pension (HOOPP), ample affordable parking, and an emphasis on work-life balance.
cons: There can be an initial 'coldness' to the work environment. It's a large campus with many different types of services and it can lack a family feel. There is also areas with large turn-over, so longer employed staff have a tendency to not trust/welcome newbies.

pros: Initial pay is more or less on par with the industry average. No benefits for contract staff. Mostly friendly and competent coworkers. Upper management is friendly and competent.
cons: Zero room for advancement and growth. Severe budget constraints. Questionable managerial practices - no overtime is authorized, yet overtime work is expected due to chronic understaffing. Questionable, often unethical middle management practices.

pros:
- Great benefits
 - Laid back atmosphere
 - Great working environment
 - Good work, life balance
 - Helpful co-workers
cons:
- Very bureaucratic
 - Limited room for growth and career advancement
 - Depending on area and department, tasks can be monotonous
 - Salary could be better
 -
